caption: Table 1: Our bounds on n for subspace estimation (ignoring restrictions on ymax and λ).
description: This table summarizes the upper and lower bounds on the number of points (n) required for differentially private subspace estimation, categorized by whether a weak or strong subspace estimator is used.  The bounds are expressed in terms of the rank of the subspace (k), the dimension of the ambient space (d), and the accuracy parameter (λ).  Note that the restrictions on ymax and λ are ignored for simplicity of presentation.

caption: Table 1: Our bounds on n for subspace estimation (ignoring restrictions on ymax and λ).
description: This table presents the upper and lower bounds on the sample complexity (n) required for differentially private subspace estimation.  The bounds are categorized by whether they are for "weak" or "strong" subspace estimators, which are determined by the multiplicative singular-value gaps in the input dataset. The table ignores restrictions on the parameters ymax (maximum easiness) and λ (utility parameter) for simplification.  It shows that the necessary number of samples to achieve certain accuracy in subspace estimation decreases with "easiness" of the data.
